abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the China Gansu and Inner
            Mongolia Poverty Reduction Project were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately satsifactory.
            Some lessons learned included: 1) timely availability of
            adequate counterpart funding seems to be a chronic issue in
            Bank-financed rural projects in China; 2) integrating
            project activities with the borrower's own programs and
            project implementing units within the existing institutional
            system ensures a higher degree of ownership, enabling better
            delivery of funding and technical services; 3) close
            leadership attention at various levels and in various forms,
            especially at the provincial and county levels by the
            responsible vice governors, county mayors and county party
            secretaries is fundamental to successful project
            implementation; and 4) for successful implementation of
            projects with agricultural activities, it is important to
            have enough flexibility in implementation allowing responses
            to natural disasters and market conditions in particular.
